title: Data Format & Import
text: GRootR reads CSV files directly exported GPR processing software (e.g., ImpulseRadar, REFLEXW, GPR-SLICE). manual preprocessing required. typical export looks like :

title: Data Format & Import
text: Row 1 — CRS metadata. Skipped automatically (skip = 1). Row 2 — Column headers. Rows 3+ — Data. detected root group consecutive rows: critical columns GRootR : N., Node, X[SRS units], Y[SRS units], Depth[m], optionally Survey.

title: Data Format & Import
text: standard GPR exports, defaults work box: equivalent :
code: library(GRootR)  df <- prepare_root_data("gpr_export.csv") df <- load_root_csv("gpr_export.csv", sep = ",", skip = 1, root_id_col = "N.") df <- split_survey_column(df, survey_col = "Survey", plot_position = 4) df <- convert_coordinates(df, x_col = "X[SRS units]",                           y_col = "Y[SRS units]", z_col = "Depth[m]")

title: Data Format & Import
text: GPR software uses different column names:
code: df <- load_root_csv("my_data.csv", sep = ";", skip = 0,                     root_id_col = "RootNumber")  df <- convert_coordinates(df, x_col = "Easting", y_col = "Northing",                           z_col = "DepthMeters")

title: Data Format & Import
text: Survey column typically encodes scan metadata composite string: split_survey_column() splits _ extracts plot ID: don’t need plot ID, skip :
code: Survey_2024.10.29_001_A_converted   │       │        │   │     │   │       │        │   │     └── processing status   │       │        │   └──────── plot ID (position 4)   │       │        └──────────── scan number   │       └───────────────────── date   └───────────────────────────── prefix # Default: 4th part → "A" df <- split_survey_column(df, plot_position = 4)  # If your plot ID is elsewhere: df <- split_survey_column(df, plot_position = 3) df <- prepare_root_data("data.csv", survey_col = NULL)

title: Data Format & Import
text: GRootR preserves whatever CRS coordinates . specify EPSG code building segments: Use projected CRS (meters). Geographic CRS (degrees) produce meaningless distances areas.
code: # Polish CS2000 zone 7 (common for GPR data from Poland) segments <- process_all_roots(df, crs = 2178)  # UTM zone 33N segments <- process_all_roots(df, crs = 32633)

title: Data Format & Import
text: joining roots trees, provide spatial file tree stem positions points: tree data needs ID column (name) point geometry. CRS matching handled automatically join.
code: library(sf) trees <- st_read("trees.shp")  # Or from CSV: trees <- read.csv("trees.csv") |>   st_as_sf(coords = c("X", "Y"), crs = 2178)

title: Getting Started with GRootR
text: GRootR processes raw CSV data exported GPR software pipeline transforms point data spatial segments geometric metrics, 2D/3D morphology estimates, inter-tree competition analysis.

title: Getting Started with GRootR
text: simplest approach uses prepare_root_data(). defaults match standard GPR export format — just point CSV: step step: happens internally: load_root_csv() — skips CRS metadata header row, reads CSV, fills missing N. values (root identifier appears first row root — continuation rows empty) split_survey_column() — extracts plot identifier composite Survey string (e.g., "Survey_2024.10.29_001_A_converted" -> "") convert_coordinates() — converts X[SRS units], Y[SRS units], Depth[m] numeric X, Y, Z; negates depth -surface = negative CSV uses different column names, adjust parameters accordingly. See vignette("data-format") details.
code: library(GRootR)  df <- prepare_root_data("path/to/gpr_export.csv") df <- load_root_csv("gpr_export.csv")   # skips CRS header, fills N. -> ROOT_ID df <- split_survey_column(df)            # extracts plot ID from Survey column df <- convert_coordinates(df)            # X[SRS units] -> X, Y, Z

title: Getting Started with GRootR
text: Convert root node points line segments compute geometric metrics: creates sf object row line segment two consecutive root nodes, columns: length_3d — 3D Euclidean distance (meters) azimuth — bearing north, 0-360 degrees inclination_angle — angle horizontal plane (degrees) slope_category — “horizontal”, “slight”, “moderate”, “steep”, “vertical” orientation — binary: “vertical” “horizontal” pX, pY, pZ — start point coordinates kX, kY, kZ — end point coordinates

title: Getting Started with GRootR
text: spatial file tree stem positions: join_nearest_tree() spatially matches segments within max_dist meters tree point. propagate_tree_name() ensures segments ROOT_ID inherit tree identity, even one segment close enough match.
code: library(sf) trees <- st_read("trees.shp") |>   st_zm() |>   select(Name, geometry)  joined <- join_nearest_tree(segments, trees, tree_id_col = "Name", max_dist = 1.5) joined <- propagate_tree_name(joined, tree_id_col = "Name")

what: Step 4: Root and tree level metrics
title: Getting Started with GRootR
code: joined <- calc_root_length(joined)           # total_length_root per ROOT_ID joined <- calc_tree_length(joined)           # total_length_tree per TREE_ID joined <- assign_depth_class(joined, bin_m = 0.2)  # 20 cm depth bins  depth_stats  <- calc_depth_stats(joined)     # depth_max, depth_mean, depth_range orientations <- count_orientations(joined)   # n_vertical, n_horizontal

title: Getting Started with GRootR
text: Build polygons representing horizontal spread tree’s root system:
code: hulls <- build_convex_hulls(joined, crs = 2178) hulls <- calc_hull_area(hulls)  sf::st_write(hulls, "root_polygons_2D.shp")

title: Getting Started with GRootR
code: merged <- merge_root_segments(joined_sf) merged <- calc_dist_to_trunk(merged, trees, tree_id_col = "Name")

title: Getting Started with GRootR
code: tree_summary <- summarise_tree_roots(joined, crs = 2178)  tree_summary$depth tree_summary$orientations tree_summary$hulls tree_summary$volume

title: Getting Started with GRootR
code: # To Excel (without geometry) joined_df <- sf::st_drop_geometry(joined) openxlsx::write.xlsx(joined_df, "root_segments_database.xlsx")  # Overlap table openxlsx::write.xlsx(overlaps, "root_competition.xlsx")  # Spatial data sf::st_write(hulls, "root_hulls.gpkg")

title: Segment Metrics Explained
text: GPR root detection produces series nodes (3D points) along detected root. GRootR connects consecutive nodes line segments, computes geometric properties segment. segment defined start point (pX, pY, pZ) end point (kX, kY, kZ).

title: Segment Metrics Explained
text: Euclidean distance 3D space start end points: length_3d=(ΔX)2+(ΔY)2+(ΔZ)2\text{length\_3d} = \sqrt{(\Delta X)^2 + (\Delta Y)^2 + (\Delta Z)^2} Computed calc_segment_length(). Units follow CRS (typically meters).

title: Segment Metrics Explained
text: Horizontal bearing start point end point, measured clockwise north (0°–360°): azimuth=atan2(ΔX,ΔY)⋅180πmod360\text{azimuth} = \text{atan2}(\Delta X, \Delta Y) \cdot \frac{180}{\pi} \mod 360 Computed calc_segment_azimuth(). Interpretation: metric describes horizontal direction root segment grows . Useful analyzing preferred root growth directions (e.g., toward water sources, away competing trees).

title: Segment Metrics Explained
text: Angle segment relative horizontal plane, degrees: inclination=atan(ΔZΔX2+ΔY2)⋅180π\text{inclination} = \text{atan}\left(\frac{\Delta Z}{\sqrt{\Delta X^2 + \Delta Y^2}}\right) \cdot \frac{180}{\pi} Computed calc_inclination(). 0° = perfectly horizontal -90° = vertical (straight ) -45° = 45° angle downward Negative values indicate downward growth. sign follows Z axis convention -surface negative.

title: Segment Metrics Explained
text: Classification segments based absolute inclination angle. Computed classify_slope(): thresholds labels customizable:
code: segments <- classify_slope(   segments,   breaks = c(10, 25, 50, 80),   labels = c("flat", "gentle", "angled", "steep", "plunging") )

title: Segment Metrics Explained
text: Binary classification: "vertical" absolute inclination > 45°, "horizontal" otherwise. Used counting proportions vertical vs horizontal root growth per tree.

title: Segment Metrics Explained
text: calc_all_segment_metrics() runs four calculations sequence:
code: segments <- calc_all_segment_metrics(segments)  # Equivalent to: segments <- calc_segment_length(segments) segments <- calc_segment_azimuth(segments) segments <- calc_inclination(segments) segments <- classify_slope(segments)

title: Segment Metrics Explained
text: segment metric per se, applied segment level. assign_depth_class() bins segment’s start depth classes: enables analysis root density orientation depth layer.
code: # Default: 20 cm bins segments <- assign_depth_class(segments, bin_m = 0.2)  # Result: 0, 20, 40, 60, 80, ... (in cm)

title: Tree-Level Analysis
text: building segments joining tree locations, GRootR provides tools aggregating data tree level: total lengths, depth profiles, 2D spread, 3D volume, inter-tree overlap.

title: Tree-Level Analysis
text: attached every segment row, can filter summarize needed.
code: library(GRootR)  # Sum of all segment lengths within one ROOT_ID joined <- calc_root_length(joined) # → adds column: total_length_root  # Sum of ALL root lengths belonging to one tree joined <- calc_tree_length(joined) # → adds column: total_length_tree

title: Tree-Level Analysis
text: Returns one row per tree :

title: Tree-Level Analysis
text: Returns per tree: ratio n_vertical / (n_vertical + n_horizontal) indicates much root system grows downward vs laterally.

title: Tree-Level Analysis
text: horizontal spread tree’s root system estimated convex hull polygon built root endpoint coordinates: hull : polygons can exported shapefiles visualization GIS software.

title: Tree-Level Analysis
text: simple volumetric estimate combining vertical range horizontal area: real_z true vertical extent per tree: max(Z) - min(Z). 3D range real_z × area_2d, giving bounding box volume m³. rough upper bound — actual root-occupied volume smaller, metric useful comparing trees sites.

title: Tree-Level Analysis
code: tree_summary <- summarise_tree_roots(joined, crs = 2178)  # Returns a list: tree_summary$depth         # depth_max, depth_mean, depth_range per tree tree_summary$orientations  # n_vertical, n_horizontal per tree tree_summary$hulls         # sf with convex hull polygons + area tree_summary$volume        # real_z, area_2d, range_3d per tree

title: Tree-Level Analysis
text: root systems neighboring trees overlap, indicates potential belowground competition water nutrients. computes pairwise intersections convex hull polygons returns: pairs non-zero overlap returned. percentages asymmetric — small tree surrounded large one show high overlap small tree’s perspective low large tree’s.

title: Tree-Level Analysis
text: far root extend parent tree? dist_to_trunk minimum distance root geometry tree stem point — essentially far closest part root trunk. Combined total_length_root, gives indication root reach vs. root complexity.
code: # First, merge all segments of each root into one geometry merged <- merge_root_segments(joined_sf)  # Then calculate distance to trunk merged <- calc_dist_to_trunk(merged, trees, tree_id_col = "Name")

title: Tree-Level Analysis
text: typical analysis table might look like:
code: library(dplyr)  final <- tree_summary$depth %>%   left_join(tree_summary$orientations) %>%   left_join(sf::st_drop_geometry(tree_summary$hulls)) %>%   left_join(tree_summary$volume)  openxlsx::write.xlsx(final, "tree_root_summary.xlsx")

text: GRootR processes raw CSV data exported GPR (Ground Penetrating Radar) software spatial root segments, computes geometric morphological metrics, enables inter-tree root competition analysis. Developed part NCN-funded project: “Zastosowanie georadaru ze skanerem 3D pomiarów zmienności systemów korzeniowych sosny zwyczajnej” (“Application Ground-Penetrating Radar 3D Scanner Measuring Variability Scots Pine Root Systems”)

text: GRootR reads CSV files directly exported GPR processing software (e.g., ImpulseRadar, REFLEXW, GPR-SLICE). typical file looks like: Key points: Row 1 CRS metadata (skipped automatically) N. column root identifier — filled first node root, empty continuation rows (filled forward automatically) Node contains node labels like node1, node2 (ordering extracted automatically) X[SRS units], Y[SRS units], Depth[m] coordinates Survey composite string containing date, number, plot ID column names configurable — defaults match standard GPR export format.

title: GRootR — Root System Analysis from GPR Data
text: step step:
code: library(GRootR)  # One-liner — uses GPR export defaults df <- prepare_root_data("path/to/gpr_export.csv") df <- load_root_csv("gpr_export.csv")          # skip=1, root_id_col="N." df <- split_survey_column(df)                    # extracts plot ID from Survey df <- convert_coordinates(df)                    # X[SRS units] → X, Y, Z

what: GRootR: 3D Visualization and Statistical Analysis of Tree Roots from GPR — GRootR-package
title: GRootR: 3D Visualization and Statistical Analysis of Tree Roots from GPR — GRootR-package
text: Tools processing analyzing tree root system data obtained Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) 3D scanning capabilities. package provides functions : Load raw CSV data exported GPR software (e.g., ImpulseRadar) Build spatial line segments consecutive root nodes Calculate geometric metrics: 3D length, azimuth, inclination, slope Join root segments tree stem locations Aggregate metrics root tree level (lengths, depth, orientations) Build 2D convex hull polygons representing root system spread Estimate 3D bounding volume root systems Analyze inter-tree root overlap competition Compute root--trunk distances

what: Raw CSV format from GPR software
title: GRootR: 3D Visualization and Statistical Analysis of Tree Roots from GPR — GRootR-package
text: input CSV direct export GPR processing software. typically contains CRS metadata header row, followed column names data. structure looks like: Key characteristics: N. Root identifier (integer). filled first node row root — continuation rows empty. Node Node label within root (e.g., "node1", "node2"). Used ordering. X[SRS units], Y[SRS units] Coordinates projected CRS. Depth[m] Depth surface (positive = ground). Survey Composite string date, number, plot ID, etc. Column names configurable functions — defaults match standard GPR export format.

title: GRootR 0.1.0
text: Data loading: load_root_csv(), split_survey_column(), convert_coordinates(), prepare_root_data() importing cleaning GPR CSV data. Segment creation: points_to_sf(), make_segments(), process_single_root(), process_all_roots() converting root points spatial line segments. Segment metrics: calc_segment_length(), calc_segment_azimuth(), calc_inclination(), classify_slope(), calc_all_segment_metrics() geometric analysis. Tree joining: join_nearest_tree(), propagate_tree_name() linking root segments tree stem positions. Root/tree metrics: calc_root_length(), calc_tree_length(), assign_depth_class(), calc_depth_stats(), count_orientations() aggregated statistics. 2D polygons: build_convex_hulls(), calc_hull_area() root system spread estimation. 3D volume: calc_real_z(), calc_range_3d() bounding volume estimation. Overlap analysis: calc_all_overlaps() inter-tree root competition. Distance: merge_root_segments(), calc_dist_to_trunk() root--trunk measurements. Pipeline wrappers: build_segments_with_metrics(), summarise_tree_roots() streamlined workflows.
